E duidui na vuna ena veigauna, ia e so na vuna bibi e rawa ni oka kina:

1. **Vakatubuqereqeri kei na Vakatorocaketaki:** Viti Levu, na yanuyanu levu duadua e Viti, e ivurevure levu ni vakatubuqereqeri kei na vakatorocaketaki ena noda vanua. Na kena sa lesi i Viti Levu e rawa ni vakarautaka vei ira na Nasi ni veiyanuyanu e dua na gaunisala ki na veiqaravi vakavuli, veiqaravi vakavuvale, kei na veiqaravi vakailavo e vueti cake ka vakavinakataki cake mai na nodra vanua dina.

2. **Veivuke Vakailavo kei na Vakacakacaka:** E levu na gauna, e vinakati me ra sa lesi i Viti Levu na Nasi ni veiyanuyanu me ra rawata na cakacaka se na veivuke vakailavo e sivia na ka e rawa ni soli ena nodra vanua dina. E rawa ni vukei ira me ra vakavinakataka na nodra bula kei na nodra vuvale.

3. **Vuli kei na Vakatorocaketaki ni Matanitu:** Eso na Nasi ni veiyanuyanu era vinakata me ra sa lesi i Viti Levu me ra vakaitavi ena vuli se na veivakatorocaketaki ni nodra mataqali cakacaka. E levu na veivakavulici kei na veivakatorocaketaki e vakayacori e Viti Levu, ka rawa ni vukei ira me ra vakavinakataka na nodra ivakarau ni cakacaka.

4. **Veika Vakailavo kei na Veivakatorocaketaki ni Bisinisi:** Eso era raica na Viti Levu me dua na vanua vinaka me ra vakatorocaketaka kina na nodra bisinisi se me ra vakaitavi ena veika vakailavo. Na kena levu na veika vakailavo kei na veivakatorocaketaki e Viti Levu e rawa ni vukei ira me ra vakayacora na nodra inaki vakabisinisi.

5. **Veisau ni Bula kei na Veivakamarautaki:** Eso na Nasi ni veiyanuyanu era vinakata me ra sa lesi i Viti Levu me ra vakila na bula ni koro levu, na veivakamarautaki, kei na veika vou. Na bula e Viti Levu e rawa ni vakaraitaka e dua na veisau mai na bula vakavanua se vakayalo ena nodra vanua dina.

The reasons island nurses want to be stationed in Viti Levu can be explained from various perspectives, depending on the context of their service, their goals, and the economic, political, or cultural situations in Viti Levu. The reasons vary over time, but some key reasons include:

1. **Career Advancement and Development:** Viti Levu, the largest island in Fiji, is a major hub for career and professional development in the country. Being stationed in Viti Levu can provide island nurses with opportunities for education, family services, and financial support that are more enhanced and accessible compared to their home islands.

2. **Financial Opportunities and Employment:** Often, island nurses need to be stationed in Viti Levu to secure jobs or financial aid that surpass what is available on their home islands. This can help them improve their own lives and those of their families.

3. **Education and Professional Development:** Some island nurses want to be stationed in Viti Levu to participate in educational programs and professional development related to their field of work. Many training and development sessions take place in Viti Levu, which can assist them in bettering their work practices.

4. **Business and Economic Development:** Some see Viti Levu as a prime location to develop their businesses or engage in economic activities. The extensive financial and developmental opportunities in Viti Levu can help them achieve their business ambitions.

5. **Lifestyle and Recreational Changes:** Some island nurses desire to be stationed in Viti Levu to experience city life, entertainment, and new activities. The lifestyle in Viti Levu can offer a change from the cultural or spiritual life on their home islands.

Itâ€™s essential to note that the reasons for wanting to be stationed in Viti Levu vary among island nurses and depend on their individual circumstances, goals, and what they hope to achieve in life.

Fijian.text:
Na yaco i Viti na matai ni daukaulotu e vakatekivu ena nodra yaco mai na daukaulotu ni Lotu Wesele (Methodist) ena 1820s. Oqo e vakayacori ena gauna ni veiliutaki vakavanua ka ra sa vakarau tiko na veimatanitu e Viti me ra ciqoma na veisau ena nodra bula vakayalo kei na nodra ivakarau ni bula.

Na nodra yaco mai na daukaulotu e Viti e sega ni vakadonui vakatotolo mai vei ira na turaga kei na lewenivanua, ka ra sotava kina na veivakatovolei kei na veika dredre. Na nodra ivakavuvuli kei na nodra ivakaraitaki ni bula vakalotu e vakavuna na veisau levu ena ivakarau ni bula vakavanua, vakabauta, kei na ivakarau ni veiliutaki ena veiyasana e Viti.

E dua vei ira na daukaulotu kilai levu ka yaco mai ki Viti ena gauna oya o David Cargill, ka tarava mai o William Cross kei na so tale. Era a yaco mai ena nodra sasaga me ra vunautaka na Vosa ni Kalou ka veisautaka na bula ni lewenivanua e Viti. Na nodra cakacaka e vakavuna na veisau levu ena bula vakayalo kei na vakasama vakavanua e Viti, ka vakavuna na kena vakadonui vakalevu na Lotu Wesele ena veiyasai Viti.

Na nodra yaco mai na daukaulotu e Viti e vakatekivu ni veisau levu ena itukutuku ni vanua, ka vakavuna na kena vakilai na veivakavoui ena vakabauta, ivakarau ni bula, kei na veiwekani ena loma ni vanua. Na nodra cakacaka e sega walega ni vakavuna na kena vakadonui na lotu Vakarisito, ia e vakavuna talega na veisau ena ivakarau ni veiliutaki, vakavuvuli, kei na vakatorocaketaki ni vanua.

English.text:
The arrival of the first missionaries in Fiji began with the arrival of Methodist missionaries in the 1820s. This happened during a time of local leadership and when the various tribal nations in Fiji were preparing to embrace changes in their spiritual lives and lifestyles.

The arrival of the missionaries in Fiji was not immediately welcomed by the chiefs and the general population, leading them to face many trials and difficulties. Their teachings and demonstration of religious life brought significant changes to traditional ways of living, beliefs, and leadership practices in various parts of Fiji.

One of the notable missionaries who arrived during that time was David Cargill, followed by William Cross and others. They came with the mission to preach the Word of God and transform the lives of the Fijian people. Their work prompted major changes in the spiritual lives and cultural mindset in Fiji, leading to the widespread acceptance of Methodism across the country.

The arrival of the missionaries in Fiji marked the beginning of significant changes in the country's history, bringing about a revival in faith, lifestyle, and relationships within the community. Their efforts not only led to the acceptance of Christianity but also brought about changes in governance, education, and the overall development of the nation.

Fijian.text:
E yaco vakacava i Viti na matai ni daukaulotu?

Na matai ni daukaulotu era yaco i Viti ena 1830 mai na lotu Wesele. O ira oqo e rau oka kina o David Cargill kei William Cross. Rau tadu yani i Lakeba, Lau ena 12 ni Okotova, 1835.

Ni bera ni rau yaco yani, sa tiko oti e Viti e dua na dauveivakatavulici ni lotu Wesele o Takai. O koya e dua na turaga ni Tonga ka lako voli me volitaki iyaya. Nona cakacaka vuni me vakatavulica na lotu vei ira na kai Viti.

English.text:
How did the first missionaries arrive in Fiji?
The first missionaries arrived in Fiji in 1835 from the Wesleyan Church. Among them were David Cargill and William Cross. They landed in Lakeba, Lau on October 12, 1835.

Before they arrived, there was already a Wesleyan teacher in Fiji named Takai. He was a man from Tonga who traveled around selling goods. In secret, he taught the Christian faith to the Fijians.

When Cargill and Cross arrived, they found that Takai's missionary work was well underway. This allowed them to successfully start their own missionary efforts in Fiji.

Ena gauna era yaco kina o Cargill kei Cross, era kunea ni sa toso vakavinaka tu na cakacaka ni kaulotu i Takai. Oqo e rawa kina vei rau me rau tekivuna vakavinaka na nodrau cakacaka ni kaulotu e Viti.
A yaco vakacava i Viti na matai ni daukaulotu?

Fijian.text:
A question in Fijian!

"A yaco vakacava i Viti na matai ni daukaulotu?" translates to "What is the chief's role in Fiji?"

In Fijian culture, the matai ni daukaulotu (chief) plays a significant role in the community. They are the traditional leaders of the village or clan and are responsible for making important decisions, resolving disputes, and maintaining social order. They are also responsible for performing ceremonial duties and upholding traditional customs and practices.

In modern Fiji, the role of the chief has evolved, and they may also be involved in local government and community development initiatives. However, their traditional role and responsibilities remain an important part of Fijian culture and society.

Ena yabaki 1875, na vanua o Viti e sotava e dua na revurevu ni mate levu, vakabibi na misila, ka vakavuna na mate levu vei ira na lewenivanua. Na misila e kauta mai ki Viti ena vuku ni veitaratara kei ira na vulagi, vakabibi na dauvolivoli kei ira na misionari mai na veiyasai vuravura, ka vakavuna na kena tarai vakaca na lewenivanua baleta ni ra sega ni tu vua na bula raraba se na isasabai vakayago me baleta na mate qo.

Na misila e dua na mate vakadomobula ka rawarawa ni kau, ka vakavuna na mate levu ena kedra maliwa na lewenivanua ni Viti baleta ni ra sega ni vakarautaki tu ena veika vakavuniwai se na vakarorogo ki na mate qo. E tukuni ni rauta ni dua na katolu ni lewenivanua e Viti e mate ena gauna ni revurevu ni misila, ka vakavuna na kena lailai vakalevu na iwiliwili ni lewenivanua ena gauna oya.

Na revurevu ni misila e 1875 e vakavuna talega na veisau ena itovo vakavanua, vakasakiti, kei na itukutuku vakaitukutuku ni vanua o Viti. E vakavuna na kena vakayagataki vakalevu na veiqaravi vakavuniwai vaka-Europe, ka vakavuna na kena vakilai na bibi ni veitaratara kei na veivuke vakamatanitu ena gauna ni leqa tubukoso. Na mate qo e vakavuna talega na kena vakasamataki vakabibi na kena gadrevi me vakataudeitaki na veika vakavuniwai kei na bula ni tiko vinaka ena veiyasai Viti.

Na revurevu ni misila ena 1875 e dua na ivakaraitaki bibi ni veika e rawa ni yaco ni sa veitaratara vakalevu na vuravura, ka vakaraitaka na bibi ni veiqaravi vakavuniwai kei na veivakabulai ena gauna ni mate levu. E vakavuna talega na kena vakasamataki vakabibi na kena gadrevi me ra vakarautaki ira na lewenivanua ena veika vakailavo kei na vakasama me baleta na veika e rawa ni yaco ena veisiga ni mataka.

English.text:
In 1875, Fiji experienced a major epidemic, particularly of measles, which led to a significant number of deaths among the population. The disease was introduced to Fiji due to interactions with foreigners, especially traders and missionaries from various parts of the world. This resulted in severe impacts on the locals, who had no immunity or physical defenses against the disease.

Measles is a highly infectious and serious disease that spread quickly, causing numerous deaths among the Fijian population because they were not medically prepared or informed about the disease. It is said that about one-third of Fijiâ€™s population perished during the measles epidemic, significantly reducing the population size at that time.

The 1875 measles epidemic also brought about changes in cultural practices, social structures, and historical narratives of Fiji. It led to the increased use of European medical services and highlighted the importance of national cooperation and aid during crises. The epidemic underscored the critical need to establish robust healthcare and well-being measures across Fiji.

The measles outbreak in 1875 serves as an important example of the consequences of increased global contact and underscored the vital role of medical services and public health measures during significant disease outbreaks. It also prompted serious consideration about the necessity for financial and intellectual resources to prepare the populace for future challenges.

E bibi sara na Saqa vei ira na lewe ni vanua o Naigani baleta ni vakadeitaka na kena maroroi na nodra itovo kei na ivakarau vakavanua, ka vakadeitaka talega na kena tomani tiko na veiwekani kei na veilomani ena kedra maliwa.

English.text:
The Saqa is a very important festival for the people of Naigani. It is held annually to commemorate the lives and work of their ancestors. The Saqa begins with the gathering of the community, followed by traditional dances, songs, and local sports. There are also feasts and communal meals.

The purpose of the Saqa is to bring the community together, remind them of their responsibilities within the village life, and honor their traditions. It is also an opportunity to share knowledge and learnings passed down from the elders. The Saqa is crucial for the people of Naigani as it ensures the preservation of their customs and traditions, and fosters connections and love among them.

Daucaka vakacava na ilavo ni Peniseni i Viti?

Fijian.text:
Mai na noqu kila me yacova na 2023, na ilavo ni penisioni e Viti e vakarautaki mai na Fiji National Provident Fund (FNPF). Na ilavo ni penisioni e rawa ni duidui me vaka na levu ni ilavo e sa bau vakacurumi (contributions) ki na FNPF, na yabaki ni nona cakacaka na lewenivanua, kei na ivakarau ni penisioni e digitaki.

Na FNPF e solia vei ira na lewenivanua eso na ivakarau ni penisioni me ra digitaka, ka vakatau tiko ena ivakarau ni bula era vinakata ni ra sa vakacegu mai na cakacaka. E rawa ni o digitaka me ra saumi vakamua e dua na iwiliwili ni ilavo (lump sum) ka qai taura na kena vo me vaka na ilavo ni penisioni vakamamaca, se me tauri taucoko me ilavo ni penisioni vakamamaca.

Na kena ivakarau dodonu ni ilavo ni penisioni e rawa ni duidui vakalevu, ka vakatau ena iwiliwili ni ilavo e sa bau vakacurumi ki na nomu akaude ni FNPF, na yabaki o sa bau cakacaka kina, kei na ivakarau ni bula o vinakata ni o sa vakacegu. E tiko talega eso na ituvatuva vou e vakarautaka na FNPF me vukei ira na lewenivanua mera vakarautaka na nodra gauna ni vakacegu, ka vakakina na nodra bula ni mataka.

Me rawa ni o kila vakavinaka na ilavo ni penisioni o na rawata mai na FNPF, e vinaka mo veitaratara sara ga kei na FNPF me baleta na nomu akaude kei na veika e rawa ni o namaka. Era na rawa ni solia vei iko na veika vakailavo e dina ka vakatau ena nomu akaude kei na veika o sa bau vakacuruma yani.

English.text:
As of my knowledge up to 2023, the pension funds in Fiji are managed by the Fiji National Provident Fund (FNPF). The pension amounts can vary based on the total contributions made to the FNPF, the number of years a person has worked, and the type of pension plan chosen. 

The FNPF offers several pension options for individuals to choose from, depending on the lifestyle they wish to maintain during retirement. You can opt to receive an initial lump sum payment and then regular pension payments, or you can choose to receive all your pension as regular annuity payments.

The exact pension arrangements can differ significantly and are influenced by the amount of money contributed to your FNPF account, your years of service, and your preferred retirement lifestyle. Additionally, the FNPF has introduced new schemes to help individuals plan for their retirement and future well-being.

To understand the specific pension benefits you are eligible for from the FNPF, it is advisable to directly contact the FNPF regarding your account and expectations. They will provide you with accurate financial information based on your account and contributions.

Na ilavo ni penisioni e rawa ni duidui me vaka na levu ni ilavo e sa bau vakacurumi (contributions) ki na FNPF, na yabaki ni nona cakacaka na lewenivanua, kei na ivakarau ni penisioni e digitaki.
Na FNPF e solia vei ira na lewenivanua eso na ivakarau ni penisioni me ra digitaka, ka vakatau tiko ena ivakarau ni bula era vinakata ni ra sa vakacegu mai na cakacaka. Na kena ivakarau dodonu ni ilavo ni penisioni e rawa ni duidui vakalevu, ka vakatau ena iwiliwili ni ilavo e sa bau vakacurumi ki na nomu akaude ni FNPF, na yabaki o sa bau cakacaka kina, kei na ivakarau ni bula o vinakata ni o sa vakacegu. Daucaka vakacava na ilavo ni Peniseni i Viti?

Na ilavo ni peniseni e Viti e dau caka ena veivakatagedegede e vica:

1. Peniseni ni Matua - E dau soli vei ira na lewenivanua era sa yabaki 65 lako cake. 

2. Peniseni ni Malumalumu - E baleti ira na lewenivanua era sa malumalumu tu vakayago se vakayalo ka sega ni rawa ni cakacaka.

3. Peniseni ni Mate ni Cakacaka - E soli vei ira era sa vakaleqai ena gauna ni cakacaka.

4. Peniseni ni Wati/Yada ni sa Mate na Wekana - E soli vua na wati se yada ni tamata cakacaka sa mate.

5. Peniseni ni Gone Luveniyali - E soli vei ira na gone era sa mai luveniyali.

English.text:
The pension funds in Fiji are organized into several categories:
1. Elderly Pension - Provided to citizens who are 65 years of age or older.
2. Disability Pension - For individuals who are physically or mentally disabled and are unable to work.
3. Work-related Death Pension - Given to those who have been affected by work-related incidents.
4. Widows/Widowers Pension - Available to the spouse of a deceased worker.
5. Orphans Pension - Provided to children who have lost their parents.
The government ensures that these funds support the well-being of its citizens during difficult times. However, the amount of money distributed depends on the poverty threshold and an individual's current income.

English.text:
In Fiji, pension funds are managed through various means such as:

1. **Government Pension**: The government provides pensions to employees who have reached the retirement age, especially those who have worked within the government sector. The pension amount depends on their length of service and their salary during their employment.
2. **Private Sector Pension Schemes**: Some large companies and businesses in Fiji offer their own pension plans for their employees. The pension funds are collected from both the employee's salary and contributions from the company.
3. **Fiji National Provident Fund (FNPF)**: The FNPF is a dedicated savings plan for workers in Fiji. Employees and their employers make monthly contributions to the FNPF. Once the employee reaches retirement age, they can withdraw their FNPF savings as their pension.
4. **Assistance Pensions**: There are also assistance programs available for individuals who have not been employed for a significant period or who are not eligible for pensions through their employment arrangements.

The amount of pension received depends on the duration of employment, the contributions made to the pension scheme, and the particular pension plan in place. It is important for workers to understand their rights and the pension schemes available to them to ensure they receive their pension funds upon retirement.

OTHER
Na cava na vuna era dauvakatabui o ira na yalewa bukete mera qoli na tobu ni ika?

Fijian.text:
Na vuna e dau vakatabui kina vei ira na yalewa bukete mera qoli na tobu ni ika e sega ni dua na ivakamacala vakasaenisi se vakavuniwai e tiko, ia e vakavurea mai na vakabauta vakavanua, itovo, kei na ivakarau ni bula ena so na vanua. Eso na vakabauta vakavanua e dau vakaraitaka ni na rawa ni vakavuna na ca vei ira na yalewa bukete se na gone era se bera ni sucu na cakacaka vakaoqo. Eso na ivakarau ni vakabauta e rawa ni vakavuna na rere se na vakabauta ni na rawa ni yaco na veika ca kevaka e sega ni muria na ivakasala vakavanua.

E tiko talega na vakasama ni na rawa ni vakaleqai ira na yalewa bukete na cakacaka bibi se na cakacaka e tiko kina na kena vakayagataki vakasivia na kaukauwa ni yago, ka rawa ni oka kina na qoli ni tobu ni ika, vakabibi kevaka e tiko na kena lavetaki se tosoi na ka bibi. Na nodra taqomaki na yalewa bukete kei na nodra bula vinaka e dau vakabibitaki ena so na itovo vakavanua, ka rawa ni vakavuna na vakatabui ni so na cakacaka.

E dodonu me nanumi ni na duidui na vakabauta kei na ivakarau ni bula mai na dua na vanua ki na dua tale, ka na rawa ni tiko na vuna vakavanua, vakayalo, se vakabula e vakavuna na vakatabui ni so na cakacaka vei ira na yalewa bukete. Na nodra vakatulewa na yalewa bukete me baleta na nodra cakacaka kei na nodra bula e dodonu me vakarorogo kina na nodra ivakasala vakavuniwai kei na nodra vakabauta vakavanua.

English.text:
The reason why pregnant women are traditionally prohibited from fishing in fish ponds is not supported by any scientific or medical explanation, but it stems from local beliefs, customs, and ways of living in some places. Some traditional beliefs suggest that such activities can cause harm to pregnant women or unborn children. These beliefs may generate fear or the conviction that bad things will happen if local advice is not followed.

There is also a concern that physically demanding work or tasks requiring significant physical strength might pose risks to pregnant women, and this may include fishing in fish ponds, especially if it involves lifting or moving heavy objects. Protecting the well-being and health of pregnant women is often emphasized in some cultural practices, which can lead to restrictions on certain activities.

It is important to note that beliefs and ways of life can vary from one place to another, and there could be local, spiritual, or health-related reasons behind such prohibitions for pregnant women. Pregnant women should consider listening to both medical advice and local beliefs when making decisions about their activities and health.

E dua na vuna levu era dau vakatabui kina na yalewa bukete mera qoli ena tobu ni ika baleta ni rawa ni vakaleqa na nodra bula kei na bula ni gone era bukete tiko.

One major reason why pregnant women are often prohibited from fishing in ponds is that it can endanger both their own life and the life of the unborn child. Fishing ponds are often deep and it can be difficult for anyone to breathe properly. If a pregnant woman fishes in such a pond, she might not be able to get enough air and this could harm the baby's health. 

There is also a risk of serious injury if she falls or gets hurt while fishing in the pond. This could severely affect both the mother and the unborn child. 
Although fishing can be enjoyable, pregnant women should be cautious because they are carrying a baby. It is better for them to stay at home and be mindful of their diet to ensure the baby remains healthy.

The practice of burial, particularly the custom of burying women in the land of their husbandâ€™s family, is a traditional custom followed in some regions and cultures. Several reasons contribute to the continuation of this practice, including:

1. **Clan Leadership and Kinship:** In certain cultural traditions, leadership and status within the community are passed down through the male lineage. Burying women in their husband's land ensures that they remain a part of their husband's clan, thereby strengthening kinship and status within that clan.

2. **Marriage and Clan Transition:** Marriage traditionally signifies a woman's transition from her own clan to her husband's clan. Burying her in her husband's land symbolizes this transition and confirms her permanent place within her husband's clan.

3. **Religious Beliefs and Practices:** In some religious beliefs and cultural practices, it is believed that the deceased should be buried with their ancestors or in a place held sacred by their clan. This can result in women being buried in their husband's land to ensure their spiritual or religious standing within that community.

4. **Land and Property Ownership:** In certain customs, land and property are owned by families or clans, and burying women in their husband's land can affirm their rights to their husbandâ€™s property and land. This practice highlights their involvement in family wealth and secures their status within the new family.

5. **Respect and Honor:** Burying women in their husbandâ€™s land can also show respect and honor, highlighting their esteemed place within their new community.

It is important to note that the reasons and significance of these practices can vary based on cultural traditions, beliefs, and region. The above explanations offer a general understanding but do not encompass all scenarios in every region.

In Fijian culture, the concept of "na cava na vuna" refers to the traditional Fijian way of addressing and respecting one's elders, particularly in a village setting.

* "Na ivakarau ni bulubulutaki o ira na matavuvale ni tagane" means "The traditional way of addressing/respecting the family of the husband's side"
* "Ve i ira na matavuvale ni yalewa" means "And the family of the wife's side"

In traditional Fijian culture, when a couple gets married, the wife typically moves to the husband's village, and she is expected to respect and address her husband's family members in a specific way. Similarly, the husband is expected to respect and address his wife's family members in a specific way when visiting her village.

* When offering food or drink to an elder, use both hands to present it, and avoid eating or drinking in their presence until they have finished.

These are just some of the traditional ways of showing respect to elders in a Fijian village. Of course, modernization and urbanization have led to changes in these customs, but they are still an important part of Fijian culture and tradition.

Era daucakava vakacava na iTaukei na 'Qalu se Vakalolo'?

Fijian.text:
Na "Qalu se Vakalolo" e dua na era ni solevu se vakayagataki ni yaqona e dau vakayacori ena vuku ni so na soqo se vakacerecerei ena vanua vakaturaga se na itikotiko ni iTaukei. E dau vakayacori me baleta na soqo ni vakamau, na solevu ni vanua, na vakavinavinaka, se so tale na soqo bibi. Na yaqona (se kava) e dua na wainimate e dau vakayagataki vakalevu ena Pasifika, vakabibi ena veiyasai Viti, ka dau vakarautaki ena dua na iwalewale vakaturaga ka vakamareqeti.

Na "Qalu" e vosa vakaviti ka vakaibalebaletaka na cakacaka ni vakarautaki ni yaqona, mai na kena qalui se vakamai me yacova na kena vakarautaki me gunuva. Na "Vakalolo" e vosa talega vakaviti ka vakaibalebaletaka na soqo se magiti levu, vakabibi na kena e vakarautaki ena so na gauna bibi se soqo.

E sega ni dua na gauna vakatautauvata e rawa ni tukuni me "era" ni "Qalu se Vakalolo" baleta ni oqo e dua na iwalewale se ivakarau ni bula e dau vakayacori me vaka na kena gadrevi se na kena rairai ena soqo duidui. E tiko na kena bibi vakavanua kei na vakasakiti ena itovo kei na itukutuku vakavanua ni iTaukei, ka sa bula tiko mai na gauna makawa ka yacova mai na gauna oqo, ka vakaraitaka na nodra ivakarau ni bula, vakabauta, kei na nodra veiwekani na iTaukei.

English.text:
"Qalu se Vakalolo" is a traditional ceremonial practice involving the preparation and consumption of yaqona (kava) which is often held during significant events or gatherings in chiefly territories or iTaukei communities. These ceremonies are typically conducted for weddings, community celebrations, expressions of gratitude, or other important occasions. Yaqona (or kava) is a traditional beverage widely used in the Pacific, especially in Fiji, and is prepared in a ceremonial and highly respected manner.

The term "Qalu" refers to the entire process of preparing yaqona, from grinding or pounding it to finally mixing and serving it. "Vakalolo" refers to a large feast or banquet, especially one prepared during significant times or events. There isn't a specific time frame for when "Qalu se Vakalolo" occurs, as it is a traditional practice carried out as needed or appropriate for different events. It holds significant cultural importance and splendor within the customs and history of the iTaukei people, having been practiced from ancient times to the present, showcasing their way of life, beliefs, and relationships.

Fijian.text:
Na 'Qalu' se 'Vakalolo' e dua na kakana vakaviti ka dau vakayagataki kina na niu, suka kei na dalo se tavioka. 

E dau mua se tuki na niu me lumi. Qai dau tuki na dalo se tavioka me malumu vinaka. E dau veisautaki na kena levu me veidonui kei na levu ni niu kei na suka. Ni sa malumu vinaka na dalo/tavioka, sa qai waki vata kei na lumi ni niu. E dau vakasukari me kua ni kamikamica. 

Na Qalu e rawa ni kana ga vakakoya se me i coi ni kakana tale eso me vaka na ika, vuaka se toa vakasuasua. E kana talega vakalevu ena gauna ni magiti se solevu.

English.text:
The 'Qalu' or 'Vakalolo' is a traditional Fijian dish that uses coconut, sugar, and either taro or cassava. The coconut is grated or pounded to produce milk. The taro or cassava is then pounded until it becomes very soft. The amount used varies to match the quantity of coconut milk and sugar. Once the taro or cassava is sufficiently softened, it is mixed with the coconut milk. Sugar is added to ensure it's not overly sweet. 

'Qalu' can be eaten on its own or served as a side to other dishes like fish, pork, or chicken stew. It is also commonly enjoyed during feasts or special events. This dish is highly popular among the iTaukei (Fijian people) as it utilizes locally grown ingredients and is not difficult to prepare.

Fijian.text:
Na 'Qalu se Vakalolo' e dua na iwalewale ni vakasaqa e dau kilai levu ena itovo ni bula ni iTaukei. E dau vakayagataki ena soqo lelevu, vakamau, vakatawase ni gone, kei na soqo ni veivakamarautaki. Na kena vakacokotaki e dau vakayagataki kina na kakana vakatubu waiwai me vaka na niu, tavioka, kei na suka.

Ena kena vakasaqa, e dau vakayagataki na niu me vakalolo kina na kakana. Na kena iwalewale e dau vakayacori vakaoqo:

1. **Vakayagataki ni Niu**: Na niu e dau vakasavasavataki, qai vakadredretaki me rawa ni vakayagataki na kena wai kei na kena lolo.

2. **Vakayagataki ni Tavioka**: Na tavioka e dau vakasavasavataki, qai vakalalai se vakamareqeti me rawa ni vakayagataki ena kena vakasaqa.

3. **Vakayagataki ni Suka**: Na suka e dau vakayagataki me vakaloloma kina na kena i lolo.

4. **Vakasasaqa**: Na wai ni niu kei na kena lolo e dau vakamareqeti vata kei na tavioka kei na suka, qai vakasaqa ena dua na kuro levu me yacova ni sa malumu vinaka na tavioka kei na kena sa vakaloloma vinaka na kena i lolo.

Na 'Qalu se Vakalolo' e dua na kakana e dau taleitaki vakalevu ena vuku ni kena i tovo vakavanua kei na kena i vakarau ni vakasaqa. E dau vakayagataki talega ena soqo ni veivakamarautaki kei na soqo ni veivakabulabulataki.

English.text:
The 'Qalu or Vakalolo' is a well-known cooking method in traditional iTaukei culture. It is commonly used during big gatherings, weddings, children's birthday parties, and entertainment events. Its preparation involves using ingredients rich in natural oils such as coconut, cassava, and sugar.

In its preparation, coconut is used to create a flavorful and rich mixture. The process is typically carried out as follows:

1. **Using the Coconut**: The coconut is cleaned and grated to extract its milk and oil.
2. **Using the Cassava**: The cassava is cleaned, peeled, and either ground or mashed to be used in the cooking process.
3. **Using the Sugar**: Sugar is added to sweeten the mixture.
4. **Cooking**: The coconut milk and oil are combined with the cassava and sugar, and then cooked in a large pot until the cassava is tender and the mixture is well-infused with the coconut flavors.

The 'Qalu or Vakalolo' is a highly admired dish because of its cultural significance and the traditional method of cooking. It is also a popular choice for celebratory and rejuvenation events.

Fijian.text:
Na lovo, e dua na sala ni kena vakarautaki na kakana ena kena vakayagataki na qara kei na vatu katakata, e dua na ivakarau ni kena vakarautaki na kakana ka dau kilai levu ena veiyasai Viti kei na Pasifika. Na vuna e daucakava ka kania na lovo ena gauna e daucaka kina e so na mataqali oga me vaka na siga ni sucu, na vakamau kei na somate e rawa ni vakamacalataki ena vuku ni veika e tolu oqo:

1. **Veivakabulabulataki kei na Veivakasoqoni Vakavanua:** Na lovo e sega walega ni dua na sala ni kena vakarautaki na kakana, ia e dua talega na ivakarau ni veivakabulabulataki kei na veivakasoqoni vakavanua. Ena gauna ni soqo bibi me vaka na siga ni sucu, na vakamau, kei na somate, na lovo e vakarautaka e dua na sala me ra soqoni vata kina na lewenivanua, me ra wasea na kakana, ka vakayacora na nodra veiwekani. E vakaraitaka na yalovata, na veikauwaitaki, kei na veivakarokorokotaki ena loma ni vanua se na vuvale.

2. **Vakarautaki ni Kakana ena Vakalevu:** Na lovo e dua na sala yaga ni kena vakarautaki na kakana ena levu na kena e rawa ni vakani kina e dua na ilawalawa levu ni tamata. Oqo e bibi sara ena soqo levu me vaka na vakamau kei na somate, na vanua e dau gadrevi kina me vakarautaki na kakana me ra kania na lewenivanua era soqoni vata mai na veiyasai vuravura se na vanua duidui. Na lovo e solia e dua na sala vinaka ni kena vakarautaki na kakana ena dua na gauna vata ga, ka vakarautaka na kakana e roka vinaka ka vakamamautaka na lomadra na lewenivanua.

3. **Maroroi kei na Vakabulabulataki ni iTovo Vakavanua:** Na kena vakayagataki na lovo ena gauna ni soqo bibi e vukea talega na maroroi kei na vakabulabulataki ni itovo vakavanua. E vakaraitaka na nodra dokai na kawa tamata na nodra itovo, na nodra ivakarau ni bula, kei na nodra ivakavuvuli. Na lovo e sega ni dua walega na sala ni kena vakarautaki na kakana, ia e dua na ivakarau ni nodra ivakaraitaki na lewenivanua na nodra vakamareqeta na nodra vuvale, na nodra itovo, kei na nodra vakabauta.

Ena iwasewase levu, na kena vakayagataki na lovo ena soqo bibi e vakaraitaka na nodra veivakabulabulataki na lewenivanua, na nodra veivakasoqoni vakavanua, kei na nodra maroroi na itovo vakavanua, ka vakarautaka e dua na sala me ra vakaraitaka kina na nodra veikauwaitaki, veivakarokorokotaki, kei na nodra veivakamareqeti ena loma ni vuvale se na vanua.

English.text:
The lovo, a method of cooking food using an earth oven with hot stones, is a widely recognized traditional cooking technique in Fiji and the Pacific region. The reason why we make and eat lovo during certain events like Christmas, weddings, and funerals can be explained through these three aspects:

1. **Community Bonding and Social Gathering:** Lovo isn't just a method of cooking; it's also a social and communal activity. During significant gatherings like Christmas, weddings, and funerals, lovo provides a means for people to come together, share a meal, and strengthen their relationships. It symbolizes unity, caring, and mutual respect within the community or family.

2. **Catering for Large Groups:** Lovo is an efficient way to prepare food in large quantities, capable of feeding a large group of people. This is crucial for big gatherings such as weddings and funerals, where there is a need to cater for guests from different regions or even countries. Lovo offers an excellent way to prepare delicious food all at once, satisfying the tastes and appetites of everyone present.

3. **Preserving and Celebrating Tradition:** Using lovo during major events helps in preserving and celebrating cultural traditions. It underscores the community's respect for their customs, lifestyle, and values. Lovo is more than cooking; it is a demonstration of the communityâ€™s love for their family, culture, and beliefs.

In essence, the use of lovo during significant gatherings highlights the communityâ€™s spirit of togetherness, social cohesion, and cultural preservation, providing a way for people to display their care, respect, and love within the family or community.

2. **Vakarautaki ni Kakana ena Vakalevu:** Na lovo e dua na sala yaga ni kena vakarautaki na kakana ena levu na kena e rawa ni vakani kina e dua na ilawalawa levu ni tamata. Oqo e bibi sara ena soqo levu me vaka na vakamau kei na somate, na vanua e dau gadrevi kina me vakarautaki na kakana me ra kania na lewenivanua era soqoni vata mai na veiyasai vuravura se na vanua duidui. Na lovo e solia e dua na sala vinaka ni kena vakarautaki na kakana ena dua na gauna vata ga, ka vakarautaka na kakana e roka vinaka ka vakamamautaka na lomadra na lewenivanua.
3. **Maroroi kei na Vakabulabulataki ni iTovo Vakavanua:** Na kena vakayagataki na lovo ena gauna ni soqo bibi e vukea talega na maroroi kei na vakabulabulataki ni itovo vakavanua. E vakaraitaka na nodra dokai na kawa tamata na nodra itovo, na nodra ivakarau ni bula, kei na nodra ivakavuvuli. Na lovo e sega ni dua walega na sala ni kena vakarautaki na kakana, ia e dua na ivakarau ni nodra ivakaraitaki na lewenivanua na nodra vakamareqeta na nodra vuvale, na nodra itovo, kei na nodra vakabauta.
Ena iwasewase levu, na kena vakayagataki na lovo ena soqo bibi e vakaraitaka na nodra veivakabulabulataki na lewenivanua, na nodra veivakasoqoni vakavanua, kei na nodra maroroi na itovo vakavanua, ka vakarautaka e dua na sala me ra vakaraitaka kina na nodra veikauwaitaki, veivakarokorokotaki, kei na nodra veivakamareqeti ena loma ni vuvale se na vanua.
Na cava na vuna keda daucakava ka kania na lovo e na gauna e daucaka kina e so na mataqali oga me vaka na siga ni sucu, na vakamau kei na somate?

Fijian.text:
Na lovo e dua na kakana vakavanua bibi sara vei keda na iTaukei baleta ni vakayagataki vakalevu e na gauna ni soqo lelevu eso me vaka na vakamau, siga ni sucu kei na somate.

E na gauna vakaoqo, e dau vakayagataki kina na lovo me vakaraitaka na noda rokova ka dokai ira na vulagi se o ira eda marautaka tiko. Na kena vakarautaki na lovo e gadrevi kina na cakacaka vata kei na veivuke mai vei ira na lewe ni vanua, ka vakadeitaka ni ra na vakani vinaka ka mamau na vulagi.

E kena ikuri, na lovo e vakaraitaka talega na noda itovo vakavanua kei na kena bibi vei keda na veiwekani kei na veilomani. Na kena twelei vata na kakana, na kena biu vata e na qara ni lovo, kei na kena laki kamikamica vata e vakaraitaka na noda duavata ka veiwekani voleka.

E dina ni sa mai veisau tiko na noda itovo kei na veika eda dau vakayagataka, ia na lovo e se ivakarau ga ni kakana e bibi ka taleitaki sara vei keda na iTaukei ka na sega ni yali rawa.

English.text:
The lovo is a significant traditional food for us iTaukei because it is commonly used during major gatherings like weddings, Christmas, and funerals. On such occasions, the lovo is used to show our respect and honor towards the guests or those we are celebrating. Preparing the lovo requires collaboration and assistance from the community members, ensuring that the guests are well-fed and satisfied.

Moreover, the lovo also highlights our cultural traditions and the importance of family and love to us. The way we combine the food, place it together in the lovo pit, and savor its unified flavors, demonstrates our unity and close relationships. 

Although our customs and practices have evolved over time, the lovo remains an essential and cherished culinary tradition for us iTaukei, one that will never be lost.

Translate the following answer from Fijian into English. Make it sound as natural as possible:
I see you're speaking Fijian!
Here's a breakdown of what you said:
"Na cava na vuna keda daucakava ka kania na lovo e na gauna e daucaka kina e so na mataqali oga me vaka na siga ni sucu, na vakamau kei na somate?"
Translation:
"What's the reason we're gathering at the lovo (earth oven) at this time, and what's the purpose of our gathering, just like on a Sunday, with the elders and the chief?"
You're asking about the purpose of a gathering, specifically a traditional Fijian lovo, and wondering why it's happening at this particular time. You're also referencing the importance of the gathering, likening it to a Sunday gathering, and acknowledging the presence of elders and a chief.
Is that correct?
Na cava na vuna keda daucakava ka kania na lovo e na gauna e daucaka kina e so na mataqali oga me vaka na siga ni sucu, na vakamau kei na somate?

Fijian.text:
Na vuna levu e dau caka kina na lovo ena gauna ni oga se soqo levu me vaka na siga ni sucu, vakamau, kei na somate e vu mai na kena i tovo vakavanua kei na kena i vakarau ni bula vakavanua e Viti. E so na vuna bibi e okati kina na lovo ena soqo levu oqo e wili kina na:

1. **i Tovo Vakavanua**: Na lovo e dua na i vakarau ni vakasaqa e dau caka vakavanua ka sa i koya na kena i tovo makawa. E dau vakaraitaka na veiwekani kei na veiqaravi vakavanua.

2. **i Kanakana Levu**: Na lovo e rawa ni vakasaqa vakalevu na kakana ena dua ga na gauna. E rawa ni vakani ira na lewe levu ni matavuvale kei na vulagi era tiko ena soqo.

3. **i Kanakana Savasava**: Na kakana e vakasaqarai ena lovo e dau savasava ka bulabula, ni sa vakayagataki kina na kaukamea kei na vatu me vakasaqa kina na kakana, ka sega ni vakayagataki kina na waiwai se na kena i vakatagedegede ni katakata e vakayagataki ena stove.

4. **i Vakaraitaki ni Veidokai**: Na kena caka na lovo e dua na i vakaraitaki ni veidokai kei na veivakaturagataki vei ira na vulagi kei na lewe ni matavuvale. E vakaraitaka na nomu dau veivakabauti kei na nomu dau veivakauqeti ena gauna ni oga.

5. **i Vakarau ni Soqo**: Na lovo e dau okati ena soqo levu me vaka na siga ni sucu, vakamau, kei na somate me vaka ni sa i koya na i vakarau ni soqo vakavanua. E dau vakarautaki kina na kakana e levu ka veivakamarautaki.

6. **i Vakaraitaki ni Veikauwaitaki**: Na kena caka na lovo e vakaraitaka na nomu veikauwaitaki kei na nomu dau veinanumi vei ira na lewe ni matavuvale kei na vulagi. E dua na i vakarau ni veiqaravi kei na veivakabauti.

Na lovo e dua na i vakarau ni vakasaqa e dau taleitaki vakalevu ena Viti ka sa i koya na kena i tovo makawa ka dau caka ena gauna ni soqo levu me vaka na siga ni sucu, vakamau, kei na somate.

English.text:
The main reason we prepare a lovo during occasions or large gatherings such as Christmas, weddings, and funerals stems from traditional customs and the cultural way of life in Fiji. Some important reasons for including a lovo in these significant events are:

1. **Traditional Custom**: The lovo is a traditional cooking method deeply rooted in our culture. It symbolizes our heritage and showcases community and cultural service.

2. **Feeding a Large Crowd**: The lovo can cook a large quantity of food at once, making it feasible to cater to large family gatherings and guests during such events.

3. **Clean and Healthy Cooking**: Food prepared in the lovo is clean and healthy as itâ€™s cooked using heated stones without the use of oils or artificial heat control like in stoves.

4. **Respect and Honor**: Preparing a lovo is a sign of respect and honor towards guests and family members, demonstrating hospitality and encouragement during special occasions.

5. **Traditional Event Practice**: The lovo is a key component of major traditional events such as Christmas, weddings, and funerals, aligning with the cultural ways of celebrating together with an abundance of joyous food.

6. **Care and Thoughtfulness**: Making a lovo shows care and consideration for family and guests, reflecting a manner of service and trust.

The lovo is a beloved traditional cooking method in Fiji, embodying a long-standing custom that is practiced during major gatherings like Christmas, weddings, and funerals.

Translate the following answer from Fijian into English. Make it sound as natural as possible:

Iko daucakava vakacava na lovo?

Fijian.text:
Na kena vakarautaki na lovo e dua na ivakarau ni vakasaqaqa e kilai levu ena veiyasai Viti kei na Pasifika. E vakayagataki na kena vakasaqari na kakana ena ruku ni qele ena kena vakayagataki na vatu katakata kei na draunimoli. Eso na ivakavuvuli ena kena vakarautaki:

1. **Vakarautaka na Qara ni Lovo**: E dodonu me keli e dua na qara ena qele me rauta ni 30cm ki na 60cm na titobu, ka me rauta na kena levu ena ivakarau ni kakana mo vakarautaka.

2. **Vakarautaka na Vatu kei na Bukawaqa**: Digitaka eso na vatu e rawa ni vosota na katakata levu ka kua ni basuka rawa. Vakama e dua na bukawaqa levu ena dela ni qara me vakarautaka na vatu me katakata.

3. **Vakarautaka na Kakana kei na Draunimoli**: Vakarautaka na kakana mo vakasaqa, me vaka na uvi, dalo, ika, se manumanu vuka, ka vakarautaka talega na draunimoli me na tabonaka na kakana.

4. **Vakadavora na Vatu kei na Kakana**: Ni sa katakata vinaka na vatu, tosoya tani eso na qilaiso ka biuta na kakana ena dela ni vatu katakata. E rawa ni o tabaka na kakana ena draunimoli se na iubi ni vudi me taqomaki ka me maroroi kina na kena irairai.

5. **Tabaka na Lovo**: Ni oti na kena biu na kakana, tabaka na lovo ena draunimoli, qele, se na iubi ni vudi me kua ni curu na ea se me drodro na wai. Na kena tabonaki vinaka e vukea me maroroi na katakata ka vakavuna na kakana me saqa vakamalua.

6. **Vakawaqa na Lovo**: Me saqa tiko na kakana ena vica na aua, me vaka na levu kei na mataqali kakana. E rawa ni yacova mai na 2 ki na 8 na aua se sivia, me vaka na levu ni lovo.

7. **Vakasuka na Lovo**: Ni sa nanamaki ni sa vakarau na kakana, dolava vakamalua na lovo ka vakasuka na draunimoli kei na qele. Vakarautaka me kua ni vakacacani na kakana ena kena vakasukai.

8. **Vakarautaka na Kakana**: Ni sa vakasukai oti na kakana, e rawa ni vakarautaki me ra kania.

Na kena vakayagataki na lovo e sega walega ni vakarautaka e dua na kakana e totoka na kena tatadra, ia e vakaraitaka talega na veiwekani kei na nodra veivakamarautaki na lewenivanua ena gauna ni soqo se magiti.

English.text:
Preparing a lovo is a traditional cooking method that is well-known throughout Fiji and the Pacific. It involves cooking food underground using hot stones and banana leaves. Here are some key steps in preparing a lovo:

1. **Prepare the Lovo Pit**: Dig a hole in the ground about 30cm to 60cm deep, large enough for the amount of food you plan to cook.
2. **Prepare the Stones and Fire**: Choose stones that can withstand high heat without breaking. Build a large fire over the pit to heat the stones.
3. **Prepare the Food and Banana Leaves**: Get the food ready for cooking, such as yams, taro, fish, or poultry, and also prepare banana leaves to cover the food.
4. **Layer the Stones and Food**: Once the stones are sufficiently hot, remove some of the ashes and place the food directly on the hot stones. You can wrap the food in banana leaves or cover it with a banana leaf mat to protect it and preserve its flavors.
5. **Cover the Lovo**: After placing the food, cover the lovo with banana leaves, soil, or a banana leaf mat to keep out air and moisture. Properly covering the lovo helps retain heat and ensures the food cooks slowly and evenly.
6. **Cook the Lovo**: Let the food cook for several hours, depending on the amount and type of food. Cooking time can range from 2 to 8 hours or more, depending on the size of the lovo.
7. **Uncover the Lovo**: When the food is expected to be ready, carefully uncover the lovo by removing the banana leaves and soil. Be cautious to prevent the food from being disturbed.
8. **Serve the Food**: Once the food is uncovered, it's ready to be served and enjoyed.

Using a lovo not only results in delicious and tender food but also showcases the sense of community and celebration during gatherings or feasts.

Iko daucakava vakacava na lovo?

Fijian.text:
Oqo eso na ivakarau ni kena dau caka na lovo:

1. Kelia na lovo me rauta ni 2-3 na fiti na kena titobu. 

2. Vakabutari ira na vatu ena loma ni lovo.

3. Vakacaudrevi ira na vatu me yacova ni ra sa katakata vinaka.

4. Ni sa katakata vinaka na vatu, qai yaviraki laivi na buka kei na qilaiso.

5. Vakadavori ira na kakana (dalo, tavioka, uvi, etc) ena dela ni vatu katakata. Rawa talega ni sovaraki ira na kakana ena loma ni draunivudi se pepa ni lovo.

6. Ubia na kakana ena draunikauvula, qai bulu ena qele.

7. Laivi me rauta ni 2-3 na aua me buta kina vakavinaka.

8. Ni sa buta oti, qai kelia cake na lovo ka kania na kakana!

Oqori eso na ivakarau levu ni kena dau caka na lovo. E rawa ni duidui vakalailai na kena icakacaka ena veiyasai Viti.

English.text:
Here are some steps on how a lovo (Fijian earth oven) is typically made:
1. Dig a pit about 2-3 feet deep.
2. Line the bottom of the pit with stones.
3. Heat the stones until they are very hot.
4. Once the stones are hot enough, remove the burning wood and ashes.
5. Place the food (taro, cassava, yams, etc.) on top of the hot stones. You can also wrap the food in banana leaves or lovo foil.
6. Cover the food with coconut leaves, then bury it with soil.
7. Leave it for about 2-3 hours to cook thoroughly.
8. Once cooked, uncover the lovo and enjoy the food!

These are some of the general steps for making a lovo. The method may vary slightly in different parts of Fiji.

Iko daucakava vakacava na lovo?

Fijian.text:
Na lovo e dua na iwalewale ni vakasaqa magiti vakavanua e Viti. E dau vakayagataki ena soqo lelevu, vakamau, soqo ni matavuvale, kei na soqo vakavanua. Eda na raica mada vakacava na kena daucakava na lovo:

### Me Vakarautaki:
1. **Kau ni lovo**: E gadrevi na kau ni lovo me vaka na vuni ni vudi, vuni ni niu, se vuni ni ivi.
2. **Vatu**: E gadrevi na vatu me veivakasaqa. E vinaka me ra vatu ni uciwai baleta ni ra sega ni kabukaburaki.
3. **Gasau**: E gadrevi na gasau me vakaduria kina na kakana.
4. **Drauni niu**: E gadrevi na drauni niu me ubia kina na kakana.
5. **Kakana**: E rawa ni o vakasaqa na vuaka, ika, kakana draudrau, uvi, dalo, kei na so tale na kakana.

### iTuvatuva ni Lovo:
1. **Vakarautaka na lovo**: 
   - Cava na qele me rauta ni 1-2 futi na kena titobu.
   - Biuta na vatu ena loma ni qara.
   - Biuta na kau ni lovo ena dela ni vatu ka vakama me yacova ni sa waqa vinaka na vatu.

2. **Vakarautaka na kakana**:
   - Biuta na kakana ena gasau se so tale na ka e rawa ni vakayagataki me vaka na lovo basket.
   - O na rawa ni vakaisulu na kakana ena drauni niu me kua ni vakaleqai ena kubou.

3. **Biuta na kakana ena lovo**:
   - Ni sa waqa vinaka na vatu, biuta na kakana ena dela ni vatu.
   - Ubi na kakana ena drauni niu me vakadeitaka ni sa ubi vinaka taucoko.

4. **Kubou**:
   - Biuta na qele ni sa ubi oti na kakana ena drauni niu. E gadrevi me vakadeitaki ni sa kubou vinaka taucoko me kua ni curuma na cagi.

5. **Vakawaitaka**:
   - Biuta me rauta ni 2-3 na aua me saqa vinaka kina na kakana. Na kena balavu ni gauna e vakatau ena levu ni kakana kei na kena bibi.

6. **Sereki**:
   - Ni sa oti na gauna ni vakawaitaka, sereki na qele kei na drauni niu.
   - Kauta tani na kakana ka vakarautaka me ra kana na tamata.

Na lovo e dua na iwalewale ni vakasaqa e dau taleitaki vakalevu ena vuku ni kena i boi vinaka kei na kena i tovo vakavanua. E dau vakayagataki talega me dua na gauna ni veivakamarautaki kei na veivakauqeti vakamatavuvale kei na veiwekani.

English.text:
A lovo is a traditional Fijian method of cooking food. It is commonly used during large gatherings, weddings, family celebrations, and traditional events. Letâ€™s look at how to prepare a lovo:

### Preparation:
1. **Lovo Materials**: You need lovo materials such as banana trunks, coconut trunks, or taro leaves.
2. **Stones**: Stones are needed for cooking. River stones are preferred as they do not break easily.
3. **Bamboo Sticks**: Bamboo sticks are needed to set up the food.
4. **Banana Leaves**: Banana leaves are used to cover the food.
5. **Foods**: You can cook pork, fish, vegetables, yams, taro, and other foods.

### Lovo Procedure:
1. **Prepare the Lovo**:
   - Dig a hole about 1-2 feet deep.
   - Place the stones inside the hole.
   - Put the lovo materials on top of the stones and light them until the stones are heated well.
2. **Prepare the Food**:
   - Place the food on bamboo sticks or in a lovo basket.
   - Wrap the food in banana leaves to protect it from the soil.
3. **Place the Food in the Lovo**:
   - Once the stones are hot enough, place the food on the stones.
   - Cover the food with banana leaves to ensure it is fully covered.
4. **Cover**:
   - Put soil over the banana leaves once the food is covered. Make sure it is well-sealed to prevent air from entering.
5. **Cook**:
   - Leave it for about 2-3 hours to cook thoroughly. The cooking time depends on the amount and weight of the food.
6. **Uncover**:
   - After the cooking time is complete, remove the soil and banana leaves.
   - Take out the food and prepare it to serve.

The lovo is a popular cooking method because of its unique flavor and traditional significance. It also serves as a time for joy and bonding among family and friends.

**Solusi:**

Kamunaga o ira na wekai tagane kivei yalewa kei na nona matavuvale adalah tentang **egoisme**. Egoisme adalah sifat atau kebiasaan seseorang yang lebih mempertimbangkan kebutuhan, keinginan, atau tujuannya sendiri daripada orang lain.

prompting_state.prompt: Sa bera ni daucaka na vakawati, na cava na vuna era dauvakaraitaka kina na kamunaga o ira na wekai tagane kivei yalewa kei na nona matavuvale?

Fijian.text:
A very thought-provoking question!

In Fijian culture, the concept of "vakawati" or arranged marriage is still prevalent, especially in rural areas. While it's not as common as it used to be, it's still practiced in many villages and communities.

There are several reasons why arranged marriages are still preferred by some families:

1. **Family ties and alliances**: In Fijian culture, family relationships and alliances are highly valued. Arranged marriages are seen as a way to strengthen family bonds and create new alliances between families.
2. **Respect for tradition**: Many Fijians believe in upholding traditional practices and customs, including arranged marriages. It's seen as a way to honor their ancestors and cultural heritage.
3. **Social status and prestige**: In some cases, arranged marriages are seen as a way to improve social status or prestige within the community. For example, marrying into a prominent or wealthy family can elevate one's social standing.
4. **Economic security**: Arranged marriages can provide economic security for the couple and their families. In some cases, the groom's family may provide financial support to the bride's family, or vice versa.
5. **Parental guidance**: In Fijian culture, parents are often seen as wise and experienced guides. They may believe that they know what's best for their children and can make better decisions about their marriage partners than the children themselves.

However, it's important to note that arranged marriages can also have negative consequences, such as:

1. **Lack of personal freedom**: The couple may not have a say in who they marry, which can lead to unhappy and unfulfilling relationships.
2. **Forced relationships**: In some cases, the couple may not even know each other before the marriage, which can lead to difficulties in building a strong and healthy relationship.
3. **Domestic violence and abuse**: In some arranged marriages, the couple may not have a strong emotional connection, which can lead to domestic violence and abuse.

In recent years, there has been a shift towards more modern and Western-style relationships in Fiji, where individuals have more freedom to choose their own partners. However, arranged marriages are still an important part of Fijian culture and tradition, and many families continue to practice them.

Sa bera ni daucaka na vakawati, na cava na vuna era dauvakaraitaka kina na kamunaga o ira na wekai tagane kivei yalewa kei na nona matavuvale?

Fijian.text:
Na kamunaga ena vakawati e dua na ivakarau vakavanua e dau vakayacori ena so na vanua e Viti, ka vakaraitaka na veidokai kei na veivakavinavinakataki vei yalewa kei na nona matavuvale. Eso na vuna bibi e dau vakayacori kina na kamunaga:

1. **Veidokai kei na Veivakavinavinakataki:** Na kamunaga e dua na sala ni veidokai kei na veivakavinavinakataki vei yalewa kei na nona matavuvale ena nodra solia mai e dua na lewe ni matavuvale me watidra na tagane. E vakaraitaka na vakavinavinaka ni nona tuberi kei na nona vakavulici na yalewa me yacova na siga ni nona vakawati.

2. **Veivakabulabulataki ni Veimaliwai:** E vakarautaka e dua na vanua me rau veimaliwai kina na rua na matavuvale, ka vakadeitaka na nodrau veitokani vinaka kei na nodrau veivukei ena veigauna e muri. E vakaraitaka na nodrau sa na veiwasei na rua na matavuvale ena veika kece e muri.

3. **Veivakarokorokotaki:** E vakarokorokotaki kina na matavuvale ni yalewa ena nodra vakarautaka e dua na lewe ni matavuvale vinaka ka vakavulici vinaka me watidra na tagane. E vakaraitaka na nodra vakavinavinaka na matavuvale ni tagane ena nodra ciqoma na yalewa me dua na tiki ni nodra matavuvale.

4. **Veivakadeitaki ni Veiyalayalati:** Na kamunaga e vakadeitaka na veiyalayalati ni vakawati ka vakaraitaka na nodrau sa vakarau me rau veiyalayalati na rua na matavuvale. E vakaraitaka na nodrau sa vakarau me rau veitokoni, veivakarokorokotaki, ka veivukei ena veika kecega.

5. **Veivakarautaki ni Yau:** Ena so na itovo vakavanua, na kamunaga e vakayagataki talega me sala ni veivakarautaki ni yau, me vaka na ilavo, qele, se manumanu, ki na matavuvale ni yalewa. E vakaraitaka na nodra sa vakarau na matavuvale ni tagane me rau veimaliwai vakailavo kei na matavuvale ni yalewa.

Na kamunaga, o koya, e sega walega ni ivakarau vakavanua, ia e dua talega na ivakatakilakila ni veidokai, veivakavinavinakataki, kei na veivakarokorokotaki ena vuku ni vakawati, ka vakaraitaka na nodrau sa vakarau na rua na matavuvale me rau veimaliwai ena veika kecega.

English.text:
In Fijian culture, presenting traditional gifts during a wedding is a significant custom practiced in various parts of Fiji. It symbolizes respect and gratitude towards the bride and her family. Here are some important reasons why this custom is observed:

1. **Respect and Gratitude:** The gifts are a way of showing respect and gratitude to the bride and her family for giving a family member to marry the groom. It acknowledges the bride's upbringing and education until the day of her wedding.
   
2. **Strengthening Relationships:** It provides an opportunity for both families to meet and establish good relationships, ensuring mutual support in the future. It demonstrates that the two families will share everything going forward.
   
3. **Honor:** It honors the bride's family for providing a well-raised and well-educated family member to be the groomâ€™s spouse. It also shows the groom's family's appreciation for accepting the bride as part of their family.

Na kamunaga e dua na itovo vakavanua bibi ena noda itovo vakaviti. Era dau vakaraitaka na wekai tagane na kamunaga me ivakaraitaki ni nodra rokova ka dokai ira na wekadra yalewa kei na nona matavuvale.

Ia, e sega ni vakabibitaki na levu se sau ni iyau e soli. Na ka e bibi duadua na yalo e soli kina, me ivakaraitaki dina ni loloma kei na veinanumi.

1. As a sign of respect and honor - the kamunaga serves as a way to show respect and honor to the bride and her family.
2. To solidify relationships - giving the kamunaga symbolizes the strengthening of relationships and underscores its importance to both parties.
3. To support the brideâ€™s family - the goods provided in the kamunaga can help the brideâ€™s family in preparing for the marriage, such as purchasing household items.
4. To preserve tradition - maintaining the tradition of presenting the kamunaga is a way to uphold our cultural heritage and its significance in our lives.

The focus is not on the quantity or cost of the goods given, but on the spirit in which they are presented, as a true expression of love and consideration.

3. **Feasts and Celebrations:** A feast or celebration can be arranged to thank the fire-walkers, showing appreciation through communal gatherings that recognize their cultural role.
4. **Traditional Gifts:** Traditional items, such as masi (tapa cloth), cultural artifacts, or other items of significant cultural value may also be given as gifts, expressing community appreciation and reverence.

The fire-walking practices of the people of Beqa are a display of courage, faith, and cultural identity. The gifts they receive highlight the community's gratitude and honor for their roles in maintaining and demonstrating these valued traditions.

The gift given to the people of Beqa when they perform the fire-walking ceremony is called "vilavilairevo." Vilavilairevo is an ancient tradition in Beqa, often conducted during grand celebrations. Both men and women participate, fishing together, and then walk over burning embers without getting burned.

Vilavilairevo is a significant and highly respected practice among the people of Beqa. It showcases their strength and bravery and signifies their careful preparation and adherence to community laws, enabling them to successfully undertake such an important task.

It is a cherished tradition that the people of Beqa take pride in preserving to this day. It is an integral part of their culture and way of life.

In Fijian culture, isolating a person on Beqa Island, known as "isolisoli," is a traditional practice used to punish and rehabilitate individuals who have committed wrongdoing, such as theft, adultery, or other serious offenses. The practice is based on the belief that isolation and solitude can help the individual reflect on their actions, seek forgiveness, and make amends.

When a person is sent to Beqa Island, they are typically left alone with minimal provisions and are expected to survive on their own. This isolation is meant to humble the individual, make them appreciate the consequences of their actions, and encourage them to change their behavior.

The practice of isolisoli is also seen as a way to maintain social order and respect for traditional laws and customs. It serves as a deterrent to others who may consider committing similar offenses, and it helps to restore balance and harmony within the community.

While the practice of isolisoli may seem harsh to outsiders, it is an important part of Fijian culture and is still observed in some communities today.

Na isolisoli ka soli vei ira na lewe ni vanua o Beqa nira dautara na kama e dua na ka vakasakiti ka kilai levu ena itovo vakavanua e Viti. Na lewe ni vanua o Beqa era kilai levu ena nodra dau tara na kama, ka ra vakatokai me "bati ni tanoa" se "bati ni kama."

Na isolisoli e dau soli vei ira na lewe ni vanua o Beqa e dau okati kina na veika e vaka oqo:

1. **Tabua**: Na tabua e dua na ka bibi ena itovo vakavanua e Viti. E dau vakayagataki ena veika bibi me vaka na vakamau, veisorosorovi, kei na veivakamenemenei. Na tabua e dau vakaraitaka na dokai kei na vakarokoroko.

2. **Masi**: Na masi e dua na mataqali isulu vakavanua e Viti, ka dau vakayagataki ena soqo bibi. E dau vakasakiti na kena iubi kei na kena vakamareqeti.

3. **Iyaqona**: Na yaqona e dua na ka bibi ena itovo vakavanua e Viti. E dau vakayagataki ena veisiga ni soqo, vakabibi ena gauna ni veivakamenemenei kei na veivakadrukai.

4. **Iyaloyalo**: Na iyaloyalo e dau okati kina na veika e vaka na isulu, isulu ni vakatagi, kei na veika tale eso e dau vakayagataki ena soqo vakavanua.

5. **Kakana**: Na kakana e dau okati kina na ika, vuaka, dalo, tavioka, kei na veimataqali kakana tale eso e dau vakarautaki ena soqo vakavanua.

Na isolisoli oqo e vakaraitaka na dokai kei na vakarokoroko vei ira na lewe ni vanua o Beqa ena nodra dau tara na kama, ka vakaraitaka talega na veivakamenemenei kei na veivakadrukai vei ira na lewe ni vanua.

English.text:
The gifts given to the people of Beqa for their firewalking ceremonies are truly remarkable and well-known in Fijian culture. The people of Beqa are renowned for their firewalking skills, and they are often referred to as the "keepers of the tanoa" or "keepers of the fire."

The gifts that are commonly presented to the people of Beqa include:

1. **Tabua**: The tabua (whale's tooth) is a significant item in Fijian culture. It is used in important events such as weddings, apologies, and peace-making ceremonies. The tabua symbolizes honor and respect.
2. **Masi**: Masi is a traditional Fijian cloth, often used in major ceremonies. Its intricate designs and cultural significance make it a treasured item.
3. **Yaqona**: Yaqona (kava) is an essential part of Fijian rituals. It is commonly used during ceremonies, especially to show respect and foster camaraderie.
4. **Iyaloyalo**: This category includes items such as traditional clothing, dance costumes, and various other items used in cultural ceremonies.
5. **Kakana**: Food offerings often include fish, pork, taro, cassava, and other traditional dishes prepared for cultural events.

These gifts signify the deep respect and honor for the people of Beqa and their firewalking tradition, also reflecting camaraderie and goodwill among the community members.

English.text: What are the requirements for cash assistance for the underprivileged from the government?

Fijian.text:

prompting_state.prompt: Na cava soti na ka me vakarautaki yani kevaka ko via taura na veivuke vaka ilavo mai vua na matanitu me baleta na tiko vakalolovira?

Fijian.text:
It seems like you're asking about the process of reporting a problem or issue to the government in Fiji. Here's a general guide:

1. Identify the issue: Clearly define the problem or issue you want to report.

2. Gather information: Collect any relevant documents or evidence related to the issue. This could include photos, receipts, or any other supporting materials.

3. Find the right department: Different issues are handled by different government departments. For example, issues related to taxes would be handled by the Fiji Revenue and Customs Service, while issues related to the environment would be handled by the Ministry of Waterways and Environment.

4. Contact the department: Once you've identified the correct department, you can contact them. This can usually be done via phone, email, or in person. You can find contact information on the department's official website or in a government directory.

5. Make your report: Clearly explain the issue and provide any supporting materials. Be sure to include your contact information so they can follow up with you if necessary.

6. Follow up: If you don't hear back within a reasonable timeframe, don't hesitate to follow up. You can also consider escalating the issue to a higher authority if necessary.

English.text:
It seems like you're asking about the process of preparing to receive financial assistance from the government for situations of extreme poverty in Fiji. Here's a general guide:

1. Identify the need: Clearly define why you need financial assistance and what the specific circumstances are.
2. Gather information: Collect any relevant documents or evidence that support your situation. This could include income statements, identification, proof of residence, or any other necessary documentation.
3. Find the right department: Different types of assistance are managed by different government departments. For example, financial aid for families might be handled by the Ministry of Women, Children and Poverty Alleviation.
4. Contact the department: Once you've identified the appropriate department, you can reach out to them. This can usually be done via phone, email, or in person. Look for contact information on the department's official website or in a government directory.
5. Submit your application: Clearly explain your situation and provide all the necessary documents. Ensure that you include your contact information so they can reach you if more information is needed.
6. Follow up: If you do not receive a response within a reasonable timeframe, don't hesitate to follow up. You may also consider escalating your request to a higher authority if needed.

Na cava soti na ka me vakarautaki yani kevaka ko via taura na veivuke vaka ilavo mai vua na matanitu me baleta na tiko vakalolovira?

Fijian.text:
Ni o via taura na veivuke vaka ilavo mai vua na matanitu me baleta na tiko vakalolovira, e bibi mo vakarautaka eso na itukutuku kei na ivola me vakadeitaka na nomu kerekere. Na ivakarau ni veika e gadrevi e rawa ni duidui mai na dua na vanua ki na dua tale, ia e so na ivakarau raraba e rawa ni o vakarautaka:

1. **Itukutuku Vakatautuba**: Oqo e okati kina na yacamu taucoko, na nomu itikotiko, na nomu itukutuku ni veitaratara, kei na itukutuku ni veitaratara ni dua tale na tamata e rawa ni vakadeitaki iko.

2. **Ivakadinadina ni Yalomatua**: Oqo e rawa ni oka kina na nomu pasipote, laiseni ni draiva, se dua tale na ivola ni vakadinadina ni yalomatua e vakadeitaka na nomu ituvaki vakaloloma.

3. **Ivakadinadina ni Tiko Vakaloloma**: E rawa ni oka kina na ivola mai na tabana ni matanitu, na veika e volai ena niusiveva, se na ivakadinadina ni veivakacacani, veivakasaurarataki, se veivakalolomataki o sotava.

4. **Ivakadinadina ni Tiko Vakailavo**: Oqo e rawa ni oka kina na nomu ivakadinadina ni tiko vakailavo, me vaka na nomu ivola ni baqe, ivakadinadina ni cakacaka, se ivakadinadina ni sega ni rawa ni o cakacaka ena vuku ni nomu ituvaki vakaloloma.

5. **Ivakamacala ni Vuni Kerekere**: E bibi mo vola e dua na ivola se dua na ivakamacala ni vuni o gadreva kina na veivuke vaka ilavo, ka vakamacalataka vakamatata na nomu ituvaki kei na vuna o gadreva kina na veivuke.

6. **Ivakadinadina ni Vakawati kei na Vuvale**: Kevaka e yaga, vakarautaka na ivakadinadina ni vakawati, na ivola ni sucu ni luvemu, se dua tale na ivakadinadina ni veiwekani.

7. **Ivakadinadina ni Vakadidike ni Yavu ni Lawa**: Kevaka o sa vakayacora e dua na kerekere me baleta na tiko vakaloloma se dua tale na ituvaki vakalawa, vakarautaka na ivakadinadina ni nomu kerekere kei na kena ituvaki ena gauna oqo.

8. **Ivakadinadina ni Bula Vinaka kei na Vakasama**: Kevaka e gadrevi, vakarautaka na ivakadinadina ni nomu bula vinaka kei na vakasama, me vaka na ivola mai na vuniwai se na dauvakasama.

Ni o sa vakarautaka oti na veika e gadrevi, vakarautaki iko talega me vakayacora e dua na veitalanoa se dua na veivosaki kei na tabana ni matanitu e dau vakarautaka na veivuke vaka ilavo, me rawa ni o vakamacalataka vakavinaka na nomu ituvaki kei na vuna o gadreva kina na veivuke. Nanuma ni na vinakati mo muria na ivakarau ni kerekere ka vakarautaka na veika e gadrevi ena gauna kei na sala e gadrevi.

English.text:
When you want to receive financial assistance from the government for living in hardship, it is important to prepare certain documents and information to support your application. The requirements may vary from place to place, but here are some general guidelines you can follow:

1. **Personal Information**: This includes your full name, current address, contact details, and contact information of a person who can verify your situation.
2. **Proof of Identity**: This can include your passport, driver's license, or another identification document that confirms your identity and hardship status.
3. **Evidence of Hardship**: This could be letters from government agencies, newspaper clippings, or documentation of any abuse, harassment, or mistreatment you've experienced.
4. **Financial Status Documentation**: Provide evidence of your financial situation, such as bank statements, employment proof, or attestations that you are unable to work due to your hardship.
5. **Explanation of Need**: Write a letter or a detailed explanation of why you need financial assistance, describing your situation and the reasons for your request.
6. **Marriage and Family Documentation**: If relevant, include proof of marriage, your children's birth certificates, or any other documentation relating to family relationships.
7. **Legal Proceedings Documentation**: If you have initiated any legal claims regarding your hardship or other legal matters, provide evidence of these claims and their status.
8. **Health and Wellbeing Documentation**: If required, provide documentation about your health and mental state, such as letters from a doctor or psychologist.

After you prepare the necessary documents, be ready to attend an interview or meeting with the government department responsible for providing financial support. This will allow you to clearly explain your situation and the reasons you need assistance. Remember to follow the application guidelines and submit the required documents in the specified manner and timeframe.

Ni o via taura na veivuke vaka ilavo mai vua na matanitu me baleta na tiko vakalolovira, e bibi mo vakarautaka eso na itukutuku kei na ivola me vakadeitaka na nomu kerekere. Na ivakarau ni veika e gadrevi e rawa ni duidui mai na dua na vanua ki na dua tale, ia e so na ivakarau raraba e rawa ni o vakarautaka:
1. **Itukutuku Vakatautuba**: Oqo e okati kina na yacamu taucoko, na nomu itikotiko, na nomu itukutuku ni veitaratara, kei na itukutuku ni veitaratara ni dua tale na tamata e rawa ni vakadeitaki iko.
2. **Ivakadinadina ni Yalomatua**: Oqo e rawa ni oka kina na nomu pasipote, laiseni ni draiva, se dua tale na ivola ni vakadinadina ni yalomatua e vakadeitaka na nomu ituvaki vakaloloma.
3. **Ivakadinadina ni Tiko Vakaloloma**: E rawa ni oka kina na ivola mai na tabana ni matanitu, na veika e volai ena niusiveva, se na ivakadinadina ni veivakacacani, veivakasaurarataki, se veivakalolomataki o sotava.
4. **Ivakadinadina ni Tiko Vakailavo**: Oqo e rawa ni oka kina na nomu ivakadinadina ni tiko vakailavo, me vaka na nomu ivola ni baqe, ivakadinadina ni cakacaka, se ivakadinadina ni sega ni rawa ni o cakacaka ena vuku ni nomu ituvaki vakaloloma.
5. **Ivakamacala ni Vuni Kerekere**: E bibi mo vola e dua na ivola se dua na ivakamacala ni vuni o gadreva kina na veivuke vaka ilavo, ka vakamacalataka vakamatata na nomu ituvaki kei na vuna o gadreva kina na veivuke.
6. **Ivakadinadina ni Vakawati kei na Vuvale**: Kevaka e yaga, vakarautaka na ivakadinadina ni vakawati, na ivola ni sucu ni luvemu, se dua tale na ivakadinadina ni veiwekani.
7. **Ivakadinadina ni Vakadidike ni Yavu ni Lawa**: Kevaka o sa vakayacora e dua na kerekere me baleta na tiko vakaloloma se dua tale na ituvaki vakalawa, vakarautaka na ivakadinadina ni nomu kerekere kei na kena ituvaki ena gauna oqo.
8. **Ivakadinadina ni Bula Vinaka kei na Vakasama**: Kevaka e gadrevi, vakarautaka na ivakadinadina ni nomu bula vinaka kei na vakasama, me vaka na ivola mai na vuniwai se na dauvakasama.
Ni o sa vakarautaka oti na veika e gadrevi, vakarautaki iko talega me vakayacora e dua na veitalanoa se dua na veivosaki kei na tabana ni matanitu e dau vakarautaka na veivuke vaka ilavo, me rawa ni o vakamacalataka vakavinaka na nomu ituvaki kei na vuna o gadreva kina na veivuke. Nanuma ni na vinakati mo muria na ivakarau ni kerekere ka vakarautaka na veika e gadrevi ena gauna kei na sala e gadrevi.
Na cava soti na ka me vakarautaki yani kevaka ko via taura na veivuke vaka ilavo mai vua na matanitu me baleta na tiko vakalolovira?

Fijian.text:
Kevaka ko via taura na veivuke vaka ilavo mai vua na matanitu me baleta na tiko vakalolovira, e dodonu mo vakarautaka eso na ka bibi me vaka na:

1. iVola ni kerekere - Mo vola e dua na ivola ni kerekere ka tukuna kina na vuna o gadreva kina na veivuke kei na levu ni ilavo o gadreva. 

2. iVakadinadina ni nomu a vakaleqai ena gauna ni waluvu - Oqo e rawa ni okati kina na itaba ni vakacaca, ripote mai vei ira na ovisa se tabana ni veivakatorocaketaki.

3. iVakadinadina ni lavo cu mai na cakacaka se bisinisi - Kevaka e vakaleqai na nomu cakacaka se bisinisi ena gauna ni waluvu, e dodonu mo vakaraitaka na ivakadinadina ni lavo cu.

4. Tukutuku ni akaude mai na baqe - Me vakaraitaki na ituvaki ni nomu akaude ena gauna ni waluvu.

5. iVola ni veivakadonui mai vei ira na iliuliu ni koro se yasana - E rawa ni vukea na kena vakadonui na nomu kerekere kevaka e tokoni mai vei ira na iliuliu.

Na veika oqo ena vukea na tabana ni matanitu mera kila na nomu ituvaki dina ka vakadonuya na nomu kerekere. Ia mo nanuma ni bibi mo vakarautaka vakavinaka na nomu ivola ni kerekere kei na veika e gadrevi me rawa ni ciqomi.

English.text:
If you want to receive financial assistance from the government for flood relief, you should prepare the following important documents:

1. Application Letter - Write an application letter explaining why you need the assistance and the amount of money you require.
2. Proof of Damage from the Flood - This can include photos of the damage, reports from the police, or documentation from any development agencies.
3. Proof of Income Loss from Work or Business - If your work or business was affected by the flood, you need to provide evidence of income loss.
4. Bank Account Statements - Show the status of your bank accounts during the time of the flood.
5. Approval Letters from Village or Provincial Leaders - Having support from local leaders can help get your application approved.

These documents will help the government understand your situation and approve your request. Remember, it's important to thoroughly prepare your application and all necessary documents to ensure it is accepted.
